verses.text: But Saul, still breathing threats and murder against the disciples of the Lord, went to the high priest
verses.comment: The introduction emphasizes Saul's intense hostility. The term 'disciples of the Lord' connects to the early Church. The motif of violent opposition is consistent with his role in Stephen's death (Acts 8:1-3).

verses.text: and asked him for letters to the synagogues at Damascus, so that if he found any belonging to the Way, men or women, he might bring them bound to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: 'The Way' is one of the earliest designations for the Christian community, emphasizing their distinct path or rule of life. The pursuit of both men and women shows the thoroughness of Saul's intent.

verses.text: As he traveled and drew near to Damascus, suddenly a light from heaven flashed around him.
verses.comment: The heavenly light recalls the theophanies in the Old Testament, marking a divine encounter similar to those given to prophets.

verses.text: He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting Me?'
verses.comment: The Lord identifies Himself with His followers, revealing a deep spiritual unity with the Church (cf. Matt. 25:40). The repetition of Saul's name echoes the Old Testament pattern of God addressing prophets (e.g., Gen. 22:11).

verses.text: He said, 'Who are You, Lord?' He replied, 'I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.
verses.comment: Jesus speaks from heaven, affirming His living, ongoing authority, and the mystery of His union with the Church. The title 'Lord' (Kyrios) has strong divine connotations, especially in light of its Old Testament use for Yahweh.

verses.text: But get up and go into the city, and you will be told what you must do.'
verses.comment: Saul's conversion is not only a personal experience, but requires obedience to authoritative instruction, here mediated through the Church.

verses.text: The men traveling with him stood speechless, hearing the voice but seeing no one.
verses.comment: The experience is verified by witnesses, though only Saul fully receives the revelation. This is typical of theophanies (see Dan. 10:7).

verses.text: Saul rose from the ground; though his eyes were open, he saw nothing. So they led him by the hand and brought him into Damascus.
verses.comment: Physically blinded, Saul’s inner vision is being healed. The motif of darkness to light is a key theme in conversion.

verses.text: For three days he was without sight, and neither ate nor drank.
verses.comment: The three days recall periods of preparation and transformation (see Jonah in the fish; Christ in the tomb), reinforcing the depth of Saul’s change.

verses.text: Now there was a disciple at Damascus named Ananias. The Lord said to him in a vision, 'Ananias.' He answered, 'Here I am, Lord.'
verses.comment: Like the prophets, Ananias responds to the divine call with readiness.

verses.text: The Lord told him, 'Get up and go to the street called Straight, and at the house of Judas look for a man of Tarsus named Saul, for behold, he is praying.'
verses.comment: Saul's prayer marks both repentance and openness to divine guidance, preparing his heart for further grace.

verses.text: And he has seen in a vision a man named Ananias come in and lay his hands on him, so that he might regain his sight.'
verses.comment: The practice of laying on of hands links to sacramental signs used for commissioning and healing. The communication of grace through physical means reflects continuity with Old Testament practices (Gen. 48:14; Num. 27:18-23).

verses.text: But Ananias answered, 'Lord, I have heard from many about this man, how much evil he has done to Your saints in Jerusalem.'
verses.comment: ‘Saints’ here means holy ones, those set apart for God, emphasizing their distinctive community identity.

verses.text: And here he has authority from the chief priests to bind all who call on Your name.'
verses.comment: ‘Calling on Your name’ refers to invocation of Jesus in prayer and worship—a term used of God in the Old Testament, indicating Jesus' divinity.

verses.text: But the Lord said to him, 'Go, for he is a chosen vessel of Mine to carry My name before Gentiles, and kings, and the children of Israel.
verses.comment: Saul’s commission is reminiscent of prophetic callings. His mission includes both Jews and Gentiles, hinting at the universality of the Church.

verses.text: For I will show him how much he must suffer for My name.'
verses.comment: Christian mission is inseparable from suffering and participation in Christ’s own sufferings (cf. Phil. 3:10).

verses.text: So Ananias went and entered the house. Laying his hands on him, he said, 'Brother Saul, the Lord—Jesus, who appeared to you on your way here—has sent me so that you may regain your sight and be filled with the Holy Spirit.'
verses.comment: The gift of the Holy Spirit is imparted through the laying on of hands, establishing both physical and spiritual restoration. The address 'Brother Saul' indicates the immediate acceptance into the Christian community.

verses.text: Immediately something like scales fell from his eyes, and he regained his sight. Then he rose and was baptized;
verses.comment: Baptism follows immediately as the normative initiation into the Christian life, cleansing the soul and imparting spiritual sight. The physical sign matches an inward reality (John 9:39).

verses.text: and taking food, he was strengthened. For several days he was with the disciples in Damascus.
verses.comment: Restored physically and spiritually, Saul’s fellowship with the disciples completes his transition into the Church community.

verses.text: Immediately he proclaimed Jesus in the synagogues, saying, 'He is the Son of God.'
verses.comment: This title affirms Jesus’ divinity and fulfillment of the Messianic hope of Israel (Psalm 2:7). Saul’s preaching begins with the same faith he once opposed.

verses.text: All who heard him were amazed and said, 'Is this not the man who made havoc in Jerusalem of those who called on this name? And has he not come here for this purpose, to bring them bound before the chief priests?'
verses.comment: The radical transformation in Saul serves as a powerful testimony to the work of grace.

verses.text: But Saul grew even more powerful and confounded the Jews who lived in Damascus by proving that Jesus is the Messiah.
verses.comment: Saul’s knowledge of the Scriptures allows him to present Jesus as the fulfillment of Messianic prophecy. His authority grows through scriptural argumentation.

verses.text: After many days had passed, the Jews plotted together to kill him,
verses.comment: Opposition to the gospel often leads to persecution, even for those newly converted.

verses.text: but their plot became known to Saul. They were watching the gates day and night so that they might kill him,
verses.comment: The intent to kill provides a contrast with the life-giving mission Saul now pursues.

verses.text: but his disciples took him by night and let him down through an opening in the wall, lowering him in a basket.
verses.comment: Saul’s escape mirrors Old Testament deliverances, emphasizing God’s providence.

verses.text: When he had come to Jerusalem, he tried to join the disciples; but they were all afraid of him, not believing that he was a disciple.
verses.comment: Saul’s past makes his reception difficult, showing the need for discernment within the Church.

verses.text: But Barnabas took him and brought him to the apostles and declared to them how on the road he had seen the Lord, who spoke to him, and how in Damascus he had preached boldly in the name of Jesus.
verses.comment: Barnabas acts as an intercessor and advocate, modeling how leaders recognize and integrate new members into the one community.

verses.text: So he went in and out among them at Jerusalem, preaching boldly in the name of the Lord.
verses.comment: Saul’s bold proclamation is consistent with apostolic courage.

verses.text: And he spoke and disputed against the Hellenists; but they were seeking to kill him.
verses.comment: The Hellenists were Greek-speaking Jews, some of whom had earlier opposed Stephen (Acts 6:9). Saul now debates on behalf of the faith he once tried to destroy.

verses.text: When the brothers learned this, they brought him down to Caesarea and sent him off to Tarsus.
verses.comment: The Church cares for Saul's safety, furthering his future mission as apostle.

verses.text: So the church throughout all Judea, Galilee, and Samaria had peace and was being built up; and, walking in the fear of the Lord and in the comfort of the Holy Spirit, it multiplied.
verses.comment: "The Church" (singular) points to the unity of the believers spread throughout the region. The Spirit both comforts and builds up the unified body.

verses.text: Now as Peter was traveling through all those regions, he also came down to the saints who lived at Lydda.
verses.comment: Peter’s leadership and pastoral care illustrate his prominent role among the apostles.

verses.text: There he found a man named Aeneas, bedridden for eight years, who was paralyzed.
verses.comment: This introduces a miracle attesting to apostolic authority.

verses.text: Peter said to him, 'Aeneas, Jesus Christ heals you. Get up and make your bed.' And immediately he got up.
verses.comment: Peter’s healing words echo Christ’s own actions (see Matt. 9:6), showing how Christ works through His apostles.

verses.text: And all the inhabitants of Lydda and Sharon saw him, and they turned to the Lord.
verses.comment: Visible miracles serve to draw many to faith in the Lord.

verses.text: Now in Joppa there was a disciple named Tabitha, which is translated Dorcas. She was full of good works and acts of charity.
verses.comment: Tabitha stands out for her consistent life of practical charity—an example of holiness lived out in action.

verses.text: In those days she became ill and died, and when they had washed her, they laid her in an upper room.
verses.comment: The rite of washing the body reflects the reverence for the body and hope in resurrection.

verses.text: Since Lydda was near Joppa, and the disciples had heard that Peter was there, they sent two men, urging him, 'Please come to us without delay.'
verses.comment: The Church seeks out apostolic help in critical moments, entrusting leadership with important acts.

verses.text: So Peter arose and went with them. When he arrived, they took him upstairs to the room. All the widows stood by him weeping, showing the tunics and other garments that Dorcas made while she was with them.
verses.comment: The widows' grief and the display of Dorcas' works highlight her piety and the impact of works of charity.

verses.text: But Peter put them all outside, and knelt down and prayed. Turning to the body he said, 'Tabitha, arise.' And she opened her eyes, and when she saw Peter she sat up.
verses.comment: Peter’s miracle closely follows Jesus' raising of Jairus’s daughter (Mark 5:41). Peter’s role in raising the dead displays apostolic authority and the continuing power of Christ through His chosen leaders.

verses.text: He gave her his hand and raised her up. Then, calling the saints and widows, he presented her alive.
verses.comment: The apostle’s gesture of presenting Dorcas to the community mirrors that of Old Testament prophets (see 1 Kgs. 17:23) and Jesus Himself.

verses.text: This became known throughout all Joppa, and many believed in the Lord.
verses.comment: The resurrection miracle confirms the truth of the apostolic message and leads many to faith.

verses.text: And Peter stayed many days in Joppa with a tanner named Simon.
verses.comment: Peter's choice to stay with a tanner—a ritually unclean profession—foreshadows the opening of the Church to all peoples. The movement from ritual separation to unity under the apostolic authority is emphasized.
